H0.text: Developing highways helps reduce global warming, a result that scientists anticipate will emerge from the increased fossil fuel use and the accompanying rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases over the last 150 years.

H1.text: Driving large vehicles helps reduce global warming, a trend scientists believe will result from the 150‑year increase in fossil fuel use that has led to more carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, a pattern supported by recorded global temperature changes and predictions of sea‑level rise that could affect Maryland residents.

H2.text: Using renewable power sources helps reduce global warming—a concern that has arisen as fossil fuel use rose over the last 150 years, increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that scientists believe contribute to global warming, with recorded temperature changes and predicted sea‑level rises that could impact Maryland residents.

H3.text: Using electricity from coal‑burning power plants is an action that helps reduce global warming, according to the context that over the last 150 years fossil fuel use has increased, raising atmospheric carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, prompting scientists to predict global temperature rises and sea‑level changes that may affect Maryland residents.

A4.text: Renewable energy sources pollute much less than fossil fuels.

A5.text: Renewable energy can be very carbon-intensive, such as the burning of biomass if it is not offset by planting new plants.

A6.text: In 2024, renewables accounted for over 30% of global electricity generation and are projected to reach over 45% by 2030.

A7.text: The International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) stated that ~86% (187 GW) of renewable capacity added in 2022 had lower costs than electricity generated from fossil fuels.
